links.description:
So Google is retiring legacy Google Apps accounts. https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2022/01/google-tells-free-g-suite-users-pay-up-or-lose-your-account

I grabbed the opportunity with both hands. Google has done enough over the past 10 years to want me to unwind my exposure to them.

Luckily I only use Google Apps for a single (wildcard) email address on my personal domain. It wasn't too hard to switch to Fastmail.

One surprising benefit: much be...

links.title: FunctionCompile‚ÄîWolfram Language Documentation
links.description: FunctionCompile[f] generates a compiled code function from a pure function. FunctionCompile[{f1, f2, ...}] generates a list of compiled code functions from a list of pure functions. FunctionCompile[<|k1 -> f1, k2 -> f2, ...|>] generates an association of compiled code functions from an association of Wolfram Language functions. FunctionCompile[defs, fspec] uses the local auxiliary definitions defs.

links.title: Data Structures‚ÄîWolfram Language Documentation

links.title: botfights | wordle
links.description:
Write a bot to fight at WORDLE‚§¥. 
quick start

First, clone the botfights-sdk‚§¥ repository

$ git clone https://github.com/botfights/botfights-sdk.git
$ cd botfights-sdk/wordle/python

Edit the play() function in the sample bot (play takes a string like "-----:00000,arose:31112,amend:31211" and should return your next guess like "abbey")
Test your bot locally

$ python wordle.py bot wordlist.txt sample-bot.play 10

Once your bot is ready to fight ...

links.title: Idris 2: Quantitative Type Theory in Practice
links.description:
Dependent types allow us to express precisely what a function is intended to
do. Recent work on Quantitative Type Theory (QTT) extends dependent type
systems with linearity, also allowing precision in expressing when a function
can run. This is promising, because it suggests the ability to design and
reason about resource usage protocols, such as we might find in distributed and
concurrent programming, where the state of a communication channel c...

A 44-year-old man presented with a 2-week history of mild left leg weakness. At the
age of 6 months, he had undergone a ventriculoatrial shunt, because of postnatal hydrocephalus
of unknown cause. When he was 14 years old, he developed ataxia and paresis of the
left leg, which resolved entirely after shunt revision. His neurological development
and medical history were otherwise normal. He was a married father of two children,
